context: Hypercholesterolemia in this model is, in part, due to the associated proteinuria which is known to increase cholesterol production and serum cholesterol level. The elevation of exhaled breath isoprene found in the CKD rats is consistent with earlier studies by Capodicasa et al. who found marked increase in exhaled isoprene in patients with end-stage renal disease and its further rise after hemodialysis procedure. There is evidence that skeletal muscle is an important source of the extra-hepatic production of isoprene. This supposition is supported by the finding of marked reduction of exhaled breath and venous isoprene in patients with muscular dystrophy and its increased levels with physical exercise and leg movement during sleep in humans [30–32]. However, elevation of exhaled breath in CKD animals shown here and in ESRD patients shown by Capodicasa et al. is unlikely to be due to its increased production in the skeletal muscle. This is because CKD is associated with muscle atrophy and depressed exercise capacity. The exhaled breath contents of three aldehydes, pentanal, hexanal, and heptanal steadily rose during the six week observation period in the normal animals which had maintained normal growth pattern.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene and isoprene are related as isoprene is a volatile organic compound (VOC) that can be produced from the metabolism of certain compounds, including 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene. The study discusses the elevation of exhaled isoprene in chronic kidney disease (CKD) rats, suggesting a metabolic link, although it does not directly explore the relationship between these two compounds. The focus is primarily on isoprene's role as a biomarker in CKD rather than a detailed interaction with 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene.
